text: Let not them that wait on thee, O Lord GOD of hosts, be ashamed for my sake: let not those that seek thee be confounded for my sake, O God of Israel.
text_kjv: Let not them that wait on thee, O Lord GOD of hosts, be ashamed for my sake: let not those that seek thee be confounded for my sake, O God of Israel.
text_niv: May those who hope in younot be disgraced because of me,O Lord, the Lord Almighty;may those who seek younot be put to shame because of me,O God of Israel.
text_esv: Let not those who hope in you be put to shame through me, O Lord GOD of hosts; let not those who seek you be brought to dishonor through me, O God of Israel.
text_nlt: Don’t let those who trust in you be ashamed because of me,O Sovereign LORD of Heaven’s Armies.Don’t let me cause them to be humiliated,O God of Israel.
text_msg: Don't let those who look to you in hopeBe discouraged by what happens to me,Dear Lord! God of the armies!Don't let those out looking for youCome to a dead end by following me—Please, dear God of Israel!
text_nasb: May those who wait for You not be ashamed through me, O Lord GOD of hosts; May those who seek You not be dishonored through me, O God of Israel,
context: Psalm 69 is a lament, a deeply personal plea from David (though some scholars debate authorship). David, in dire straits, cries out to God amidst intense suffering, likely facing persecution, betrayal, and false accusations. The historical context can be loosely tied to periods of internal strife within Israel or opposition from neighboring kingdoms, possibly during Saul's reign or Absalom's rebellion, where David was unjustly targeted and his reputation attacked. "Lord GOD of hosts" is a powerful title evoking God's sovereignty and might, emphasizing His control over earthly and spiritual armies. It was a title used in times of national crisis, appealing to God's power to defend His people. The phrase "God of Israel" further connects David's plight to the covenantal relationship between God and His chosen nation. David's concern extended beyond himself; he worried about the repercussions his situation might have on the faith of others. Shame was a powerful societal force in ancient Israel, and public humiliation could significantly impact one's standing and influence. David's prayer, therefore, reflects a concern not only for his personal safety but also for the preservation of God's reputation and the encouragement of those who looked to Him for salvation. His enemies were actively seeking to discredit him and, by extension, the God he served. He was desperate to ensure his struggles didn't weaken the faith of the righteous.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 69:6 reveals several crucial aspects of the relationship between God and humanity. First, it highlights the concept of vicarious suffering. David fears that his own shame and humiliation will negatively impact the faith of others who trust in God. This echoes the later New Testament theme of Christ's suffering on behalf of humanity, bearing the shame and sin of the world so that believers would not be condemned. David's concern demonstrates a profound sense of responsibility for the spiritual well-being of his community. Second, the verse underscores the importance of God's reputation. David recognizes that his circumstances reflect not only on himself but also on the God he serves. He is acutely aware that his enemies will use his suffering to mock God and undermine faith. This resonates with the Old Testament emphasis on God's name being hallowed and not blasphemed. Third, it emphasizes the nature of true faith as actively seeking God. The verse differentiates between those who merely claim to believe and those who earnestly "seek" Him. This seeking implies a dedicated pursuit, a persistent prayer, and a deep desire for a relationship with God. Finally, this verse highlights the human tendency to stumble when witnessing the suffering of others, particularly those who profess faith. It acknowledges the reality that doubt and confusion can arise when believers face hardship. David's prayer is a desperate plea that God would safeguard the faith of those vulnerable to discouragement.
application: In modern application, Psalm 69:6 speaks powerfully to our roles as witnesses for Christ in a challenging world. When we face trials, our actions and responses profoundly impact those around us, especially other believers and those considering faith. Therefore, we must strive for integrity and faithfulness, even amidst suffering. We must be mindful of how our struggles might be perceived by others and avoid actions that could bring reproach upon the name of God or weaken the faith of others. This means maintaining a positive attitude, continuing to pray, and seeking opportunities to share our faith even when it's difficult. Furthermore, this verse calls us to support and encourage fellow believers who are facing adversity. We should be sensitive to the potential for discouragement and proactively offer prayer, practical assistance, and words of hope. It is a reminder that our faith journey is not solitary. We are part of a larger body of believers, and we have a responsibility to uplift and strengthen one another. We should actively seek opportunities to bear one another's burdens, recognizing that our actions can either solidify or undermine the faith of others. When witnessing someone experiencing hardship, avoid judgment and instead offer empathy and understanding. Remember, their struggles may be testing their faith, and our support can be instrumental in helping them persevere. Finally, reflect on our own relationship with God. Are we truly "seeking" Him? Are we actively pursuing a deeper understanding of His word and a more intimate connection with Him through prayer? Our own spiritual growth will not only strengthen our faith but also enable us to be a stronger witness for Christ in the world.
prayer: Lord God of hosts, God of Israel, I come before you today acknowledging my own vulnerability and the potential impact my life has on those around me. Forgive me for the times I have faltered in my faith, causing others to doubt or stumble. Grant me strength to endure trials with grace and integrity, that my life may be a testament to your unwavering love and faithfulness. Protect those who are seeking you, especially those struggling with doubt and discouragement. Let not their faith be shaken by the challenges they face. Surround them with your peace and provide them with the support they need. Help me to be a source of encouragement and hope to others, reflecting your love and compassion. Guide me to speak words of life and to act in ways that honor your name. I trust in your power and sovereignty, knowing that you are able to keep us from falling and to present us faultless before the presence of your glory with exceeding joy. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Why does David express concern for others instead of solely focusing on his own suffering? He understands his position as a leader and the impact of his actions on the faith community. His personal struggles can cause others to question God's faithfulness. He prioritizes God's reputation and the well-being of believers.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: How does this verse relate to the New Testament concept of bearing one another's burdens? It foreshadows the idea that believers are interconnected and responsible for supporting each other spiritually. Just as David feared his struggles would harm others, we are called to actively help those in need.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: What does it mean to "wait on" the Lord? It signifies a posture of trust, dependence, and expectant hope. It involves patiently enduring difficult circumstances while maintaining faith in God's promises and provision. It is an active waiting, filled with prayer and reliance on God's word.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: How can we apply this verse in situations where we witness injustice or suffering in the world? We can advocate for justice, support victims, and pray for God's intervention. We can also share our faith and hope, demonstrating God's love and concern for those who are hurting.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: Does this verse suggest that our personal failures can invalidate our faith? No, it acknowledges that failures can damage our witness and affect others, but true repentance and reliance on God's grace can restore our integrity and effectiveness. God forgives and restores.
